awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:RUI:P2C2: Extending Key Records of Holocene Climate Change and Glacier Fluctuations in the North Pacific Region Using Subfossil Wood from Southeastern Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop a multi-millennial, tree-ring chronology from subfossil trees exposed by retreating glaciers in Southeast Alaska to precisely calendar-date Holocene glacier fluctuations and compare them with a new record of climate seasonality. The multi-millennial tree-ring chronology will be used to extend reconstructions of spring and summer temperatures and build new records of winter storminess by analyzing traumatic resin ducts in annual tree rings. The winter storminess reconstruction is related to the strength of the Aleutian Low-pressure system (AL) and its analysis has the potential to transform the understanding of cold season ocean-atmospheric variability in the North Pacific. Specific goals of this project are to: 1) Generate 2,000-year-long records of wintertime AL along with summer temperature variability to determine how they responded to past climate forcing. 2) Use dendrochronology to precisely date when seven land-terminating and two tidewater glaciers advanced and retreated during the last 4000. 3) Test the hypothesis that the most extensive Holocene glacier advances in south coastal Alaska occurred when cooler summer air temperatures (reduced melt) coincided with a strengthened AL (increased snowfall). 


The potential Broader Impacts include the collection of time-sensitive archives of buried wood that would be available to the scientific communities for multi-disciplinary investigations. The project will generate new reconstructions of spring-summer temperature, winter storminess and glacier advance/retreats to better understand the dynamics of climate-glacier mass balance and the North Pacific decadal variability at millennial time scales. This project will provide training for four undergraduate students as part of their undergraduate thesis including field work, data analysis and presentation of the results. The researchers will engage in public outreach by giving two talks at Glacier Bay National Park. In addition, a dendrochronology workshop in partnership with the Hoonah Indian Association and the Hoonah Native Forest Partnership will be organized in the Native Alaskan Village of Hoonah with the goal of engaging students in skill-based technique centered on the collection and analysis of tree-ring records.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated past climate and landscape change of Southern Alaska using tree-ring records as proxies for environmental change. A primary focus of this research involved finding and sampling logs that were run over and preserved by advancing glaciers in the past several millennia. By measuring the rings and surface color changes of these new collections, we now have a 3870-year-long tree-ring record that is being used to understand the causes of past temperature variability and contextualize recent warming trends. This record is now one of the longest tree-ring records from the high latitudes with the possibility of extending it further back in time.

By using tree-rings to reconstruct past climate change, we found that temperature change and winter weather in the Gulf of Alaska region corresponds with climate variability across the Western and Midwest US. Thus, our work has bolstered the idea to use these far-afield records to reconstruct large-scale variability of climate in the North and Tropical Pacific. Results indicate that the North Pacific climate variability known to affect hydroclimate and marine resources can undergo sudden shifts in the multi-year duration of their phasing. This is important because another shift in this phasing will likely occur in the future and fundamentally change the cycles of drought and fish populations that respond to this climate forcing.

Another focus of this project was to understand the patterns and causes of past glacier fluctuations. We found that past glacier fluctuations in the southern Alaska generally tracked solar variability over the last millennium. The overall patterns and climate sensitivity of glaciers in Northwest North America was discussed in an extensive review paper about the paleoenvironments of the Northeast Pacific region. The region's long-term glacier fluctuations over glacial-interglacial time scales were driven by changes in El Nino and the Aleutian Low Pressure System, which affected the position and intensity of winter storm tracks in the North Pacific.

The final part of this research involved determining how past climate changes affected the old-growth forests of Southeast Alaska. We discovered that certain forests next to glaciers can serve as natural global-change laboratories because fluctuating glacier microclimates have amplified the past temperature changes experienced by these forests. Thus, they serve as useful case studies that demonstrate how adaptive forests are when faced with the type of large and fast temperature changes that we expect in the next century. We found that species-specific climate sensitivity of different trees instills stability and resilience when these forests experience accelerated temperature changes. We also found that past changes in climate have likely caused prehistoric episodes of forest dieback that were previously thought to be exceptional to today. This paleoenvironmental research has implications for how today's forest systems will respond to future climate change.

Results from this project were published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at International Conferences. Six undergraduate thesis projects were supported by this NSF funding. Outreach included collaborations with journalists, public science courses for retirees, visitors of a National Park, as well as science workshops and co-production of knowledge with four Alaska Native communities.
